attributes.body_part: With some verbs in this frame, the Body_part involved in the action is specified by the meaning of the verb and cannot be expressed separately.  For example,
attributes.message: This FE identifies the Message that the body movement conveys.
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the Manner in which the body movement occurs.
attributes.instrument: An Instrument that the Communicator uses to gesture to the Addressee together.
attributes.addressee: Addressee only occurs in the Body-movement frame in sentences which are blends with Communication.  Where it occurs, it is typically a PP Complement:
attributes.means: An act performed by the Communicator that results in the successful transfer of a Message.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the Time when the body movement occurs.
attributes.purpose: The purpose of the body movement.
attributes.degree: This FE identifies the Degree to which the event occurs.
attributes.re-encoding: An alternative description of the Body_movement.
attributes.goal: Goal is any expression that identifies the endpoint of movement.
attributes.result: This FE identifies the Result of an event.
attributes.internal_cause: Body movement may be prompted by either some outside phenomenon or occurrence, or by an Internal_cause, the Agent's mental or emotional state. Internal_cause is expressed in a PP Complement.
attributes.depictive: This FE identifies any Depictive phrase describing the actor of an action.
attributes.external_cause: Cause is something in the external environment that causes the Agent to move part of his/her body.  Cause is usually expressed in a PP Complement:.
attributes.coordinated_event: An event that the Agent perceives and responds to by moving in coordination with it.
attributes.subregion: This FE specifies the subregion of the body that is involved with movement.
attributes.duration: The period of time during which the movement of a Body_part occurs.
attributes.cognate_event: This FE identifies the event noun of the verb.
attributes.agent: The Agent uses some part of his/her body to perform the action. Agent occurs as the External Argument.
attributes.source: Source is the place from which the Body_part is moved.
attributes.area: Area identifies any expression describing a region in which the motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  (This FE should be contrasted with Place.)
attributes.path: Path identifies the trajectory of motion of the Body_part without specifying a start or end point.

Expansion(Event).description: An  Agent or non-human Cause causes an Item to change its physical size.  The Size_change of an Item may be explicitly indicated or characterized in terms of Initial_size and/or Result_size.  In the default case, expansion is along all dimensions, but sometimes the Dimension of expansion is incorporated or made explicit.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.instrument: This FE identifies the Instrument with which the Agent causes the expansion of the Item.
attributes.purpose: This FE identifies the Purpose for which the Agent causes the expansion of the Item.
attributes.rate: Rate identifies the rate of change of the value.
attributes.means: This FE identifies the Means by which the Agent brings about the expansion of the Item.
attributes.cause: The Cause is a non-human entity which brings about the change in size.
attributes.result_size: Result_size is typically expressed in a PP Complement headed by to.
attributes.initial_size: Initial_size is rarely expressed without Result_size also being explicit.  Initial_size generally occurs in a PP-from Complement.
attributes.size_change: Size_change identifies the amount by which the size of an Item changes.
attributes.elapsed_time: The Elapsed_time is the amonut of time in which the change occurs.
attributes.agent: With some words in this frame, an Agent who causes the change in size of the Item may be present. The Agent typically occurs as the External Argument of a verb.
attributes.explanation: The Explanation denotes a proposition from which the main clause (headed by the target) logically follows. This often means that the Explanation causes the target's proposition, but not in all cases.
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the Manner of performing an action.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the Time when the Agent causes the Item to expand.
attributes.group: This FE identifies the Group in which an Item changes size.
attributes.co-variable: The feature that the size of the Item is varied in step with.
attributes.dimension: Change of size may be limited to or described in terms of a single Dimension.
attributes.item: The Item is frequently the External Argument of verbs or the NP Object if an Agent is expressed.
attributes.place: This FE identifies the Place where the Agent cause the expansion of the Item.

Telling(Event).description: A Speaker addresses an Addressee with a Message, which may be indirectly referred to as a Topic. Instead of (or in addition to) a Speaker, a Medium may also be mentioned.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.time: The Time during which the Speaker informs the Addressee of the Message.
attributes.manner: The Manner describes the way in which the Speaker delivers the Message.
attributes.addressee: The Addressee receives the Message from the Speaker.
attributes.message: The Message is the communication produced by the Speaker.
attributes.descriptor: This FE identifies a characteristic or description of the telling event.
attributes.speaker: The Speaker is the sentient entity that produces the Message.
attributes.means: The Means describes the way the Speaker accomplishes the task of giving the Addressee the Message.
attributes.iterations: The FE Iterations is used for expressions that indicate the number of times an event or state (of the kind denoted by the target in its clause) has taken place or held.
attributes.medium: This FE is the Medium in which the Message is expressed.
attributes.place: Place is the location in which the Speaker informs  the Addressee of the Message.
attributes.topic: The Topic is a general description of the content of the Message.
attributes.communicative_force: This FE indicates the Communicative_force or authority with which the Message is expressed. This FE is often denoted by words such as "officially," "formally," "technically," etc.

Change(Event).description: An Agent or Cause causes an Entity to change, either in its category membership or in terms of the value of an Attribute. In the former case, an Initial_category and a Final_category may be expressed, in the latter case an Initial_value and a Final_value can be specified.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.final_category: The category that the Entity belongs to after it has undergone the change.
attributes.attribute: A characteristic of the Entity for which a value can be assigned or determined by calculation, measurement , or observation.
attributes.re-encoding: This FE presents the current frame as an integral part of a larger conceptualization expressed by another frame.
attributes.manner: Any description of the  event causing the change of the Entity which is not covered by more specific FEs, including epistemic modification (probably, presumably, mysteriously), secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). It may also indicate salient characteristics of the Agent that also affect the action (deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
attributes.agent: The sentient entity that effects a change in the Entity.
attributes.containing_event: This FE denotes an event that occurs or state of affairs that holds at a time that includes the time during which the event or state of affairs reported by the target occurs and of which it is taken to be a part.
attributes.period_of_iterations: The length of time from when the event denoted by the target began to be repeated to when it stopped.
attributes.time: The time at which the change of the Entity is caused.
attributes.initial_value: The value that the Attribute has before the change takes place.
attributes.means: An intentional action performed by the Agent (or event resulting from the Cause) that produces a change in the Entity.
attributes.cause: An event that causes a change in the Entity.
attributes.final_value: The value that the Attribute assumes as a result of the change that the Entity is caused to undergo.
attributes.entity: The abstract or concrete thing or situation that the Agent causes to change.
attributes.circumstances: Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
attributes.place: The location where the change of the Entity is caused.
attributes.initial_category: The category of which the Entity is a member before the Agent causes a change.
attributes.role: The particular role that the Agent plays in the Cause_change event.
attributes.event_description: In general, this FE is used for phrases that describe the clause of the target as a whole.
attributes.duration: Duration denotes the length of time from the beginning of a continuous situation (the one denoted by the target) to its end. In many cases, the continuous situation is a dynamic action which is ongoing, while in others it is simply an undifferentiated state.
attributes.explanation: A state of affairs that the Agent is responding to in bringing about the change in the Entity.
attributes.purpose: An action that the Agent intends to accomplish by effecting a change in the Entity.
attributes.degree: The extent to which the initial and final categories or values differ from each other.

Cause_change_of_phase(Event).description: A Cause or Agent causes a Patient to undergo a change of phase.  The Result of the change may be given, along with the Initial_state and the Circumstances under which the change can occur.  Note that this frame contrasts with Cause_change_of_consistency in that this frame describes causation of a change of a Patient between different phases (i.e. solid to liquid or frozen to "unfrozen").   Bob melted the butter.    Sally defrosted the chicken to eat for dinner.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.purpose: This FE identifies the purpose for which the Agent affects the Patient,
attributes.degree: Degree to which the Agent changes the phase of the Patient
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the Manner in which the Agent intentionally affects the Patient.
attributes.hot_cold_source: The Hot_cold_source is the source of the heat or cool.   We  froze  the fish  on ice  .
attributes.patient: The Patient undergoes a change of phase brought about by the Agent.
attributes.duration: The length of time for which the Agent changes the phase of the Patient.
attributes.cause: The Cause is the non-Agent which brings about the change in the Patient. The sun melted the ice.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the Time at which the change of phase occurs.
attributes.speed: The Speed at which the change of phase occurs.
attributes.result: Result is the result of the change of phase.  the butter  was melted to a runny consistency
attributes.container: This FE identifies the Container that holds the Patient whose phase is being changed .Melt the butterin a medium-sized pan.
attributes.depictive: The Depictive describes the state of the Agent or Patient at the time of phase change.
attributes.instrument: This FE identifies the Instrument with which the Agent intentionally affects the Patient.
attributes.agent: The Agent causes the Patient to change phase.
attributes.medium: The Medium is the substance which surrounds the Patient and facilitates its phase change.
attributes.subregion: The Subregion describes which part of a larger whole is being affected.
attributes.initial_state: This is the original state of the Patient. The rock  was solidified  from its molten state  .
attributes.circumstances: This FE identifies the Circumstances under which the phase change occurs
attributes.means: This FE identifies the Means by which the Agent intentionally affects the Patient
attributes.place: This FE identifies the place where change of phase occurs.

Legal_rulings(Event).description: An Authority with the power to make decisions hands down a Finding over a question presented in a formal or informal Case.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.defendant: The person about whom the Authority passes a judgment or Finding.
attributes.re-encoding: This FE presents the current frame as an integral part of a larger conceptualization expressed by another frame. The frame expressed by the target typically corresponds to a Means action within the frame expressed by the Re-encoding, but not necessarily
attributes.means: This FE identifies an action that the Authority performs in order to return the verdict.
attributes.duration: The amount of time that a Finding holds.
attributes.explanation: The Explanation for the Finding.
attributes.authority: The Authority (which may be the jury, judge, magistrate or court) decides on the Finding.
attributes.communicative_force: This FE indicates the Communicative_force or authority with which the ruling event operates (often denoted by words such as "officially," "formally," "technically," etc.).
attributes.case: This FE describes the question on which the Authority gives a Finding.
attributes.finding: This FE identifies the outcome of the Authority's deliberation or consideration.
attributes.place: Where the Finding takes place.
attributes.purpose: This FE identifies the purpose why the Authority returns a particular Finding.
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the Manner in which the Authority acts.
attributes.legal_basis: This FE indicates the basis in law of a Finding.
attributes.particular_iteration: Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states. In addition, most expressions of Particular_iteration indicate which instance of the series is being referred to.
attributes.time: When the Authority gives his Finding.
attributes.circumstances: The Circumstances under which the ruling was reached.

Bearing_arms(Event).description: A Protagonist has (or does not have) a Weapon.  The Degree to which the Protagonist is armed may also be described.  The Protagonist is normally a human but may be a device that has subsidiary weapons.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.place: The location where a Protagonist carries a Weapon.
attributes.time: The time at which the Protagonist carries a Weapon.
attributes.degree: The amount of Weapons that the Protagonist has (relative to some standard).
attributes.protagonist: The individual that possesses a Weapon.
attributes.weapon: The destructive device that the Protagonist has with them.

Giving(Event).description: A Benefactor confers a Beneficial_situation to a Beneficiary.  Unlike in Commerce_scenario, the recipient is not necessarily required to pay for the good or service that they receive.  Therefore, the element of benevolence is profiled.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.beneficiary: The Beneficiary is person or thing that receives an advantage from the Benefactor.
attributes.benefactor: The Benefactor is the person or thing that gives an advantage to the Beneficiary.
attributes.degree: The degree to which the Beneficiary gains an advantage from the Benefactor.
attributes.subset: A Subset of beneficial situations is selected from the set of beneficial situations in a specific domain, though the domain need not be explicitly named.
attributes.beneficial_situation: The Beneficial_situation is the item or action that is given to or done for the Beneficiary by the Benefactor.  A change of possession can, but does not have to occur.
attributes.domain: The Domain describes the type of advantage that is conferred.
attributes.purpose: The Purpose for which the Donor gives the Theme to the Recipient.
attributes.potential_recipient: The entity that ends up in possession of the Theme.
attributes.manner: The way that the Donor lacks the Theme.
attributes.explanation: The Explanation for which the Donor gives the Theme to the Recipient.
attributes.offerer: The person that begins in possession of the Theme and offers it to the Potential_recipient .
attributes.depictive: A description of the Donor, Recipient, or Theme given independently of the giving event per se.
attributes.imposed_purpose: The Recipient's intended purpose for the Theme.
attributes.theme: The entity that the Donor has just given to the Recipient.
attributes.circumstances: The Circumstances are the conditions under which the Theme is given. I give my services free of charge.
attributes.time: This FE indicates the Time when the Post_giving event occurs.
attributes.means: The Means by which the Donor gives the Theme to the Recipient.
attributes.place: The Place where the Donor gives the Theme to the Recipient.
attributes.period_of_iterations: The length of time from when the event denoted by the target began to be repeated to when it stopped.
attributes.donor: The individual that has just given the Theme to the Recipient and no longer has the Theme.
attributes.recipient: The individual that has just come into possession of the Theme.

Name_conferral(Event).description: This  frame contains words that talk about how Speakers name Entities.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.name: The linguistic expression by which Speakers refer to the Entity.
attributes.entity: The entity that Speakers refer to by using the Name.
attributes.manner: Manner of performing an action
attributes.place: Where the event takes place.
attributes.time: When the event occurs.
attributes.speaker: The person who uses the linguistic expression (Name) to refer to the Referent.
attributes.name_source: This frame element is the person or thing whose name was chosen by the Speaker to give to the Entity.
attributes.instrument: The instrument with which an intentional act is performed.
attributes.purpose: The purpose for which an intentional act is performed.
attributes.explanation: The Explanation of the intentional act.
attributes.means: An action the Speaker takes in order to accomplish the name conferral.

Arranging(Event).description: An Agent puts a complex Theme into a particular Configuration, which can be a proper order, a correct or suitable sequence, or a spatial position.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.means: An action performed by the Agent in order to arrange the Theme.
attributes.degree: The extent to which the Arranging act has occured.
attributes.location: The place in which the Theme is put into a Configuration.
attributes.instrument: An entity used by the Agent to change the Theme's Configuration.
attributes.purpose: An action that the Agent is trying to bring about by changing the Configuration of the Theme.
attributes.theme: An entity that consists of  parts which can be put into a configuration relative to each other and/or relative to their environment.
attributes.time: The Time when the arranging takes place.
attributes.manner: Any description of the arranging action which is not covered by more specific FEs, including epistemic modification (probably, presumably, mysteriously), force (hard, softly), secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). With agentive use, it may indicate salient characteristics of an Agent  that also affect the action ( eagerly, carefully).
attributes.configuration: A state that holds of the Theme or a relation that holds among the constituent parts of the Theme as a result of the arranging action.
attributes.agent: The person who causes the Theme to be in a particular Configuration.
attributes.circumstances: Circumstances identifies the situation in which an Agent arranges a Theme.

Making_arrangements(Event).description: An Agent performs a series of unspecified tasks to plan for an Event to take place at a Scheduled_time and Place.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.time: This FE describes the time at which the arrangements are made.
attributes.purpose: The Agent's motivation for arranging the Event.
attributes.scheduled_time: The time for which the Agent has arranged the Event.
attributes.means: The means used by the Agent to make arrangements for the Event to take place.
attributes.frequency: The frequency with which the Agent organizes the Event.
attributes.explanation: The cause for arranging the Event.
attributes.place: The location at which the Agent has made arrangements for the Event to take place.
attributes.agent: The person who makes arrangements for the Event to take place at a Time and Place.
attributes.manner: The way in which the Agent makes the arrangements for the Event.
attributes.event: The incident for which the Agent has made arrangements.
attributes.beneficiary: The person for whom the Event was arranged.

Use_firearm(Event).description: An Agent causes a Firearm to discharge, usually directing the projectile from the barrel of the Firearm (the Source), along a Path, and to a Goal.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.firearm: This FE identifies the Firearm that an Agent activates so that it rapidly propels a projectile.
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the manner in which an Agent uses the Firearm.
attributes.area: Area is the setting in which the projectile's movement takes place.
attributes.depictive: Depicitive phrase describing the state of a participant in the action.
attributes.iterations: This FE identifies the number of times a firearm is used.
attributes.path: This is the path along which the projectiles travel.
attributes.place: This FE identifies the place where the Agent intentionally affects the Patient.
attributes.means: This FE identifies the means by which an Agent uses the Firearm.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the Time when the Agent fires the Firearm.
attributes.source: The Source is the location of the Firearm from which projectiles originate.
attributes.agent: The self-directed entity that uses and activates the Firearm.
attributes.purpose: This FE identifies the purpose for which an Agent uses the firearm.
attributes.goal: Goal is the location the Theme ends up in, or is intended to end up in.

Committing_crime(Event).description: A Perpetrator (generally intentionally) commits a Crime, i.e. does something not permitted by the laws of society.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.manner: Any description of the Misdeed which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of a Wrongdoer that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
attributes.crime: An act, generally intentional, that has been formally forbidden by law.
attributes.means: An action taken by the Wrongdoer which accomplishes the Misdeed.
attributes.instrument: The Instrument used in committing the crime.
attributes.purpose: The state-of-affairs that the Wrongdoer is hoping to accomplish through their Misdeed.
attributes.frequency: How often the Wrongdoer commits the Misdeed.
attributes.time: The time at which a Misdeed is performed.
attributes.place: The location where a Misdeed occurs.
attributes.perpetrator: The individual who commits the Offense
attributes.explanation: A state of affairs that the Perpetrator is responding to in their Crime.
attributes.misdeed: The assessment of the Wrongdoer is based on his or her Misdeed.
attributes.severity: The Severity is the degree to which the Misdeed offends the moral sense of the Viewpoint.
attributes.injured_party: An individual who is harmed by the Misdeed of the Wrongdoer.
attributes.wrongdoer: This is the person whose Misdeed is being judged with respect to its morality.
attributes.viewpoint: The individual whose point of view is taken in assigning the judgment denoted by the target.
attributes.punishment: This FE denotes the Punishment that is specified by the statute in which the offense is defined.
attributes.victim: This FE denotes the person or entity that is badly affected by the Offense.
attributes.degree: This FE broadly picks out the degree of offense.
attributes.specification: The Specification is an additional aspect of the main crime being commited.

Assistance(Event).description: A Helper benefits a Benefited_party by enabling the culmination of a Goal that the Benefited_party has.  A Focal_entity that is involved in reaching the Goal may stand in for it.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.duration: The time period during which the Helper gives assistence to the Benefited_party.
attributes.instrument: An entity used by the Helper in service of the Benefited_party's accomplishing their Goal.
attributes.explanation: The Explanation denotes a proposition from which the main clause (headed by the target) logically follows. This often means that the Explanation causes the target's proposition, but not in all cases.
attributes.domain: The aspect of accomplishing the Goal to which the Helper's assistance is relevant.
attributes.means: An action that the Helper undertakes in service of the Benefited_party's Goal.
attributes.helper: The Helper performs some action that benefits the Benefited_party.
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the Manner in which a Helper assists a Benefited_party.
attributes.frequency: The frame element is defined as the number of times an event occurs per some unit of time. A Frequency expression answers the questions how often. It is to be distinguished from Iteration, which pertains simply to the number of times an event occurs; Iteration expressions answer the question how many times.
attributes.benefited_party: The Benefited_party receives a benefit from the action of the Helper.
attributes.degree: The measure to which the Helper's assistance brings the Benefited_party closer to accomplishing their Goal.
attributes.place: This FE identifies the Place where the Assistance occurs.
attributes.focal_entity: This FE identifies a Focal_entity involved in achieving the Goal.
attributes.goal: The desirable state of affairs that the Benefited_party is involved in and which is enabled by the Helper.
attributes.purpose: The situation that the Helper wishes to bring about by helping the Benefited_party to acheive the Goal.  Note that this FE should normally be used only when this situation is separate from the Goal.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the Time when the Assistance occurs.

Surrounding(Event).description: A Figure surrounds a Ground.  The Ground location is presented as more likely to be a known location than the location of the Figure. Some lexical units entail more-or-less complete surrounding in two or three dimensions (e.g. surround.v), while others entail surrounding on only two sides (e.g. astride.prep, straddle.v).  Like other locative relations, the Figure may be any of a movable entity, an immovable entity, or an event.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.direction: This FE identifies the Direction from a reference location (generally, the deictic center) of a path to the Figure.
attributes.directness: An indication of how closely the position of Figure matches the prototype expected from the image schema associated with the target.  This FE is normally filled by closed-class, dedicated adverbs like right, straight, and directly.
attributes.time: The Time during which the Figure is located around the Ground.
attributes.ground: The Ground is the area that the Figure surrounds.
attributes.profiled_region: The area or zone immediately external to the Ground.  This FE excludes Figure and is only used in particular constructions such as the following:
attributes.figure: The Figure is the entity located with respect to the Ground.
attributes.accessibility: An indication of how accessible the Figure is to some participant in the speech context (either the speaker or the addressee, or some other highly salient viewpoint in a narrative). This FE normally describes availability for manipulation and use, but may simply describe how easily seen the Figure is. There is a closed class of items that can fill this slot, including only 'just' and 'right' indicating ease of access.
attributes.distance: This  FE identifies the Distance between the Figure and some reference location (generally, the deictic center or the Ground).

Quarreling(Event).description: A group of Arguers (also expressible as Arguer1 and Arguer2) express incompatible opinions or beliefs about an Issue.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.frequency: The frequency with which the Arguers have a disagreement.
attributes.arguer2: The person who is being argued with by Arguer1.
attributes.depictive: A state of the Arguers, Arguer1, or Arguer2 which saliently affects the perception of the action.
attributes.arguers: A group of people in an argument.
attributes.issue: The the thing the the Arguers are arguing over or about.
attributes.amount_of_discussion: The degree to which the argument has been finished.
attributes.place: The location at which the Arguers quarrel
attributes.means: The action that the Arguers perform in order to quarrel with each other.
attributes.duration: The amount of time that the Arguers spend in the altercation.
attributes.purpose: The state-of-affairs that the Arguers or Arguer1 hope to bring about.
attributes.manner: A description of the dispute which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). It may also indicate salient characteristics of the Arguers that affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
attributes.arguer1: A person who is arguing with Arguer2.
attributes.medium: The equipment, language, or other entity that the Arguers use to pursue their argument.
attributes.time: The time when the argument takes place.

Expend_resource(Event).description: An Agent uses a Resource which is consumed and unavailable for future use.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.means: This FE identifies the Means by which an Agent exhausts the Resource.
attributes.degree: The degree to which the Resource is depleted by the Agent.
attributes.place: This FE identifies the place where the Agent exhausts the Resource.
attributes.manner: Any description of the intentional act which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of an Agent that also affect the action ( deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
attributes.purpose: The Agent uses the Resource for a Purpose.
attributes.agent: The Agent uses the Resource.
attributes.resource: The Resource is exhausted over time by being used.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the time when the Agent exhausts the Resource.

Motion_directional(Event).description: In this frame a Theme moves in a certain Direction which is often determined by gravity or other natural, physical forces. The Theme is not necessarily a self-mover.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.degree: Degree to which event occurs
attributes.place: The Place is where the motion (which is specified by a Source, Path or Goal) is located.
attributes.manner: Any expression which describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion expresses the frame element Manner. Descriptions of speed, steadiness, grace, means of motion, and other things count as Manner expressions.
attributes.time: The time at which the motion takes place.
attributes.purpose: The state-of-affairs that the Theme wishes to bring about.
attributes.depictive: Depictive phrase describing the actor of an action
attributes.speed: The Speed is the rate at which the Theme moves.
attributes.source: Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element Source. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
attributes.path: Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a Source nor a Goal (see below) expresses the frame element Path, including directional expressions:
attributes.area: This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
attributes.circumstances: The state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the Traversing event itself and any of its participants, and is merely peripherally related to the event as a whole.
attributes.explanation: A factor which explains the particular motion or manner of motion of the Theme.
attributes.result: The state of the Theme at the end of the event.
attributes.duration: The length of time that the Theme spends in motion.
attributes.point_of_contact: This FE is used for expressing some part of the Theme participant that makes contact with a horizontal surface.
attributes.theme: This is the object which moves. In many sentences this FE will be expressed as something which moves under its own power. However, this FE is not required to be an animate mover, so it is different from Self_mover.
attributes.direction: The direction in which the Theme goes.
attributes.goal: Any expression which tells where the Theme ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element Goal.
attributes.path_shape: The configuration formed by the entire Path of the Theme, taken simultaneously.
attributes.means: An event involving the Theme that results in the Theme moving in the specified way.
attributes.distance: Any expression which characterizes the extent of motion expresses the frame element Distance.
attributes.carrier: The Carrier is the means of conveyance of the Theme.
attributes.frequency: The number of times that an action occurs in a given time.
attributes.co-participant: Co-participant is an entity that participates in a coordinated way in the same event as the primary protagonist, regardless of whether the protagonist, and hence the Co-participant, is more agent- or more undergoer-like.
attributes.containing_event: An event that occurs or state of affairs that holds at the time the Traversing occurs and which the Traversing is taken to be a part of.
attributes.re-encoding: A larger conceptualization that includes the Traversing as an integral part. The Traversing expressed by the target typically corresponds to a Means action in this larger conceptualization.
attributes.self_mover: This is a sentient being or a vehicle steered by a sentient being which moves.
attributes.means_of_motion: The device or bodypart that serves to move the Theme.
attributes.new_situation: An unexpected event that affects some agent (usually the Theme), which is enabled by, and occurs after, the Traversing.
attributes.cotheme: This is the second moving object, expressed as a direct object or an oblique:
attributes.endpoints: The Source and Goal of either a single or a repeated motion taken together as Endpoints of the Path.
attributes.iterations: The frame element Iterations is used for expressions that indicate the number of times an event or state (of the kind denoted by the target in its clause) has taken place or held.
attributes.coordinated_event: The label Coordinated_event is to be used for phrases denoting an event-it does not allow states-that the Traversing is rhythmically aligned with. The Coordinated_event is conceived of as independent: it would occur regardless of the event expressed by the target, which is not even an incidental or optional sub-part of the Coordinated_event.
attributes.reciprocation: An event paired with the motion, which explains why the motion is expected. In particular,  or an action that Reciprocation is used to indicate an action that is being rewarded or punished by the motion, is paired with the motion as the other side of an agreement.
attributes.event_description: In general, this FE is used for phrases that describe the clause of the target as a whole. There are two somewhat distinct subgroups of sentence modifiers that cover this function.
attributes.period_of_iterations: The time period within which the motion event occurs repeatedly.

Bringing(Event).description: This frame concerns the movement of a Theme and an Agent and/or Carrier.   The Agent, a person or other sentient entity, controls the shared Path by moving the Theme during the motion. In other words, the Agent has overall motion in directing the motion of the Theme.  The Carrier may be a separate entity, or it may be the Agent's body. The Constant_location may be a subregion of the Agent's body or (a subregion of) a vehicle that the Agent uses.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.source: Source indicates the beginning of the path along which the Theme travels.
attributes.frequency: This frame element is used to indicate the location of a participant in cases where the multiple participants of an event are not co-located in the typical fashion.
attributes.constant_location: The Constant_location expresses the location of the Theme relative to the Carrier.  This relationship holds for the entire length of the carrying event.
attributes.place: The Place is the general area that serves as a setting for the specific motion of the Agent and Theme (with Source, Path, or Goal).
attributes.co-participant: Co_participant is an entity that participates in a coordinated way in the same event as the primary protagonist, regardless of whether the protagonist, and hence the Co-participant, is more agent- or more undergoer-like.
attributes.theme: The objects being carried.
attributes.agent: The Agent is a sentient being who physically controls the movement of the Theme via the carrier, accompanying the Theme.
attributes.carrier: The Carrier provides support for the Theme.  Movement of the Carrier results in movement of the Theme.
attributes.beneficiary: This FE describes the particpant for whom the bringing is beneficial.
attributes.period_of_iterations: This FE is minimally distinct from Duration and Duration_of final_state in that the clause described is conveyed to be iterative.
attributes.means: The actions the Agent takes to move the Theme.
attributes.purpose: The Purpose for which the Carrier or Agent carries the Theme . We had to carry the heavy weights all the way to the top of the hillto show our strength.
attributes.particular_iteration: Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.
attributes.area: Area is used for descriprion of a general area in which the carrying action takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path.
attributes.duration: Duration denotes the length of time from the beginning of a continuous situation (the one denoted by the target) to its end. In many cases, the continuous situation is a dynamic action which is ongoing, while in others it is simply an undifferentiated state.
attributes.speed: The Speed is the rate at which the carrying or transporting occurs.
attributes.explanation: Explanation denotes a proposition from which the main clause (headed by the target) logically follows. This often means that the Explanation causes the target's proposition, but not in all cases.
attributes.degree: This frame element selects some gradable attribute and modifies the expected value for it.
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the Manner  in which the Carrier or Agent carries the Theme .
attributes.time: The time in which the carrying event takes place.
attributes.distance: This FE identifies the Distance the Theme is carried.
attributes.depictive: Depictive identifies a phrase describing the Carrier, Agent or Theme.
attributes.goal: Goal identifies the endpoint of the path.
attributes.path: Path along which carrying occurs.

Communication(Event).description: A group of people (the Interlocutors or Interlocutor_1 and Interlocutor_2 together) have a conversation.  No person is construed as only a speaker or only an addressee. Rather, it is understood that both (or all) participants do some speaking and some listening--the process is understood to be symmetrical or reciprocal.  In this frame, the purpose of the conversation is generally social, rather than specifically to decide something or exchange information, or to quarrel (see Discussion and Quarreling).

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.interlocutor_1: In cases where the Interlocutors involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, this FE identifies the conversational participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as compared with Interlocutor_2. That is, Interlocutor_1 is generally encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference to the event itself generally make reference to Interlocutor_1.  Thus a Purpose (or Means, Depictive, or Manner) is construed to be that of Interlocutor_1, not necessarily that of Interlocutor_2 or the group of Interlocutors as a whole.
attributes.language: The linguistic system(s) used by the Interlocutors to discuss something.
attributes.interlocutor_2: In cases where the Interlocutors involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, Interlocutor_2 refers to the semantically and grammatically less prominent group.  It is generally encoded within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by with).  Note that it is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents. For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were plural, we would still assign it the single role Interlocutor_2.
attributes.duration: Duration is the length of time during which the communication takes place.
attributes.means: The Means by which the Communicator communicates.
attributes.time: The time at which the communication takes place.
attributes.manner: The Manner in which the Communicator communicates.
attributes.interlocutors: In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the FE role Interlocutors. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the FE Interlocutors is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Discussion frame, it is possible for the Interlocutors role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.
attributes.purpose: The Purpose for which a Communicator communicates.
attributes.topic: The Topic is the subject matter to which the Message pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by "about", but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
attributes.place: The location where the act of communication occurs.
attributes.means_of_communication: The device or system that facilitates a discussion.
attributes.depictive: The Depictive describes the state of the Communicator.
attributes.content: The wish for action on the Addressee's part  that the Speaker expresses.
attributes.addressee: The Addressee receives a Message from the Communicator.
attributes.instrument: An entity that the Speaker manipulates to get the Addressee to perform the Content.
attributes.speaker: Speaker, the person who encodes the Message, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs: The teacher phrased the question carefully.
attributes.goods: An entity that the Speaker gets the Addressee to give to them.
attributes.trigger: The Trigger is the prior communication or action to which a response is given. It can occur as an NP Object or a PP Complement.Sue answered the question.Sue responded to the questionnaire.
attributes.message: Message is a proposition or set of propositions that the Communicator wants the Addressee to believe or take for granted.
attributes.internal_cause: The response may be prompted by either some outside phenomenon or occurrence, or by an Internal_cause, the Agent's mental or emotional state.  Internal_cause is expressed in a PP Complement:
attributes.medium: The physical or abstract setting in which the Message is conveyed.
attributes.communicator: The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a Message to the Addressee.
attributes.location_of_protagonist: The location occupied by the Communicator.Does anyone e-mail the office from a phone booth?
attributes.intermediary: The Intermediary is the person who facilitates the contact.
attributes.address: This FE is used for a (metaphorical) place in a system of communication where Communicators and Addressees can access the system. You can telephone your senator at 555-5555.
attributes.frequency: This FE describes the number of times per unit of time that the Communicator conveys a Message.
attributes.communication: The information that the Communicator wishes to impart to the Addressee, often to get a particular response. In this frame the Communication is not necessarily received by the Addressee. Patients continually call in with questions.
attributes.containing_event: This FE denotes an event that occurs or a state of affairs that holds at a time that includes the time during which the discussion takes place and of which it is taken to be part.
attributes.amount_of_discussion: Amount_of_discussion applies to phrases expressing how thoroughly a Topic has been discussed.
attributes.domain: The general field or area in which the discussion takes place, or which shapes the discussion or its topic.
attributes.period_of_iterations: The length of time from when the event denoted by the target began to be repeated to when it stopped.
attributes.adequacy: The degree to which the Communicator's efforts are effective at making the Addressee understand and appreciate the Message.
attributes.amount_of_information: The amount of information exchanged when communication occurs.
attributes.quote: The Quote is the concrete record of a communication act.

Containing(Event).description: In this frame a Container holds within its physical boundaries the Contents.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.time: The time at which the Container holds the Contents.
attributes.contents: The Contents is the substance or objects contained within the physical bounds of the Container.
attributes.container: The Container is the physical object which holds within its boundaries the Contents

Manufacturing(Event).description: A Producer produces a Product from a Resource for commercial purposes.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.consumer: The Producer produces the Product for the Consumer.
attributes.time: This Fe identifies the Time when the product was produced.
attributes.purpose: This FE identifies the Purpose for which an Producer produces a Product.
attributes.product: The Product is produced by the Producer.
attributes.circumstances: This FE identifies the Circumstances under which the the product was produced.
attributes.depictive: A phrase that describes the state of the Producer or the Product during the manufacturing process.
attributes.factory: Factory identifies the particular plant where the Product is manufactured.
attributes.locus: The Locus is a description of the active zone of the Producer, where the manufacturing most saliently takes place.
attributes.resource: Resource is the material that the product is made from.
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the Manner in which a Producer creates a Product.
attributes.producer: The person or company that produces the Product.
attributes.place: This FE identifies the Place where the Product is manufactured.
attributes.instrument: This FE identifies the Instrument with which a Producer
attributes.frequency: The number of manufacturing events in a given time period.
attributes.means: This FE identifies the Means by which a Producer  creates a Product.

Social_event(Event).description: This frames describes a social event where there may or may not be a permanent or semi-permanent relationship between participants. Additionally, participants in this frame are expressed separately, as Party_1 and Party_2.  Note the difference between this frame and Social_event_collective, where participants are grouped into one collective grammatical constituent and FE.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.degree: This FE identifies the Degree to which the Social_event occurs.
attributes.party_2: Party_2 is the grammatically less prominent participant in the social event.  Party_2 can be one or more individuals.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the Time when the Social_event occurs.
attributes.party_1: Party_1 is the grammatically more prominent participant in the social event.  Party_1 can be one or more individuals.
attributes.duration: This FE identifies the Duration of time for which the Social_event is ongoing.
attributes.manner: This FE identifies the Manner in which the Social_event occurs.
attributes.place: This FE identifies the Place where the Social_event occurs.
attributes.attendees: The Attendees are the collectively construed participants of the social event.
attributes.particular_iteration: Expressions marked with Particular_iteration modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.
attributes.beneficiary: The person for whom the Social_event is held.
attributes.occasion: The Occasion for which the Social_event is held.
attributes.attendee: Attendee is used for the people who come to the Social_event.
attributes.frequency: This FE describes how often the Social_event occurs.
attributes.host: The Host is the person or organization that hosts the Social_event.  In cases where an individual stands in for an organization, the host may be marked twice.
attributes.period_of_iterations: COD: The length of time from when the event denoted by the target began to be repeated to when it stopped.
attributes.refreshment: Refreshment is used for the meal, food or drinks that are served at the Social_event.
attributes.purpose: The reason the Social_event is being held.
attributes.name: The Name of the Social_event.
attributes.social_event: This FE identifies the Social_event itself.
attributes.style: This FE identifies the Style of  the Social_event and its level of formality, indicating appropriate dress for participants and/or  the kind of activities in which they engage.

Robbery(Event).description: These are words describing situations in which a Perpetrator wrongs a Victim by taking something (Goods) from them.  In some cases, the Source location from which the Goods were taken is used to metonymically refer to the Victim.  The robbery can be done in a particular Manner (for example, forcefully) and via a specific Means (for example, by threatening the Victim).

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.manner: The Manner describes the way in which the Robbery took place.
attributes.time: The Time indicates when the Robbery occurs.
attributes.explanation: The state of affairs that the Perpetrator has in mind which leads to the decision to commit the robbery.
attributes.perpetrator: The Perpetrator is the person (or other agent) that takes the Goods away by force or threats.  Leslie robbed Kim of her watch.
attributes.goods: The Goods are anything (including labor, time, or legal rights) that can be taken away.
attributes.place: The Place is where the Robbery occurs.
attributes.purpose: The action that the Perpetrator is trying to accomplish by the robbery.
attributes.means: The Means indicates the means by which the Robbery takes place.
attributes.co-participant: Co-participant denotes a person that participates in a coordinated way in robbery event as the primary protagonist, the Perpetrator.
attributes.source: Source is the initial location of the goods, before they change location.
attributes.victim: The Victim is the person (or other sentient being or group) that owns the Goods before they are taken away by the Perpetrator.
attributes.frequency: The number of times a robbery event occurs.

Competition(Event).description: This frame is concerned with the idea that people (Participant_1, Participant_2, or Participants) participate in an organized, rule-governed activity (the Competition) in order to achieve some advantageous outcome (often the Prize).  Rank and Score are different criteria by which the degree of achievement of the advantageous outcome is judged.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.participants: This FE is used for plural NP participants in a competition.
attributes.place: Where the event takes place.
attributes.manner: The way the Participants compete.
attributes.venue: This FE is for the named venue of a competition, particularly when the place has been built for the purpose of a competition.
attributes.means: The action the Participants (or Participant_1) are involved in that constitutes a Competition.
attributes.participant_2: This FE identifies the second participant in a competition.
attributes.time: The period of time when the Competition occurs.
attributes.frequency: This FE expresses how often the Competition occurs.
attributes.score: This FE is used for the score in a game.
attributes.competition: This FE is used for the name of the competition.
attributes.rank: This FE is used for the ranked results of a competition, and is translatable into a numerical value.
attributes.prize: This FE indicates a prize won in a competition.
attributes.participant_1: This FE identifies the first (or only) participant in a competition.
attributes.duration: This FE is used to describe the length of time over which competition occurs.
attributes.degree: This FE describes the intensity of competition.
attributes.purpose: This FE is used to describe the intended outcome of the competition.

Writing(Event).description: An Author creates a Text, either written, such as a letter, or spoken, such as a speech,  that contains meaningful linguistic tokens, and may have a particular Addressee in mind.  The Text may include information about its topic, although the latter is not an FE in this frame.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.author: The Author produces a particular Text.
attributes.place: Where the event takes place.
attributes.explanation: The Explanation for creating the text.
attributes.instrument: The instrument with which an intentional act is performed.
attributes.manner: Manner of performing an action.  This frame includes some peculiar examples of manner phrases.
attributes.medium: The language in which the Text is represented or the physical materials upon which the Text is recorded.
attributes.means: This FE identifies the Means by which a Text is created.
attributes.beneficiary: Beneficiary identifies the person in whose honor or for whose benefit the Text is created.
attributes.addressee: This is the person to whom the Message is communicated. When this FE is expressed, it often appears in a prepositional phrase introduced by to, or as the direct object, or as the first object in a double object construction.
attributes.depictive: Depictive phrase describing the actor of an action
attributes.form: This FE describes the form in which the text is presented.
attributes.text: The entity which results from the act of writing or speaking.
attributes.components: The Components are the parts that the Author uses to construct the Text.  Caitlin wrote the book from memoirs she collected.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the Time at which the text is created.
attributes.purpose: The purpose for which an intentional act is performed.

Rescuing(Event).description: An Agent saves a Patient or an Asset from a Harmful_situation.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.means: The means by which the Agent rescues the Patient or Asset.
attributes.degree: The extent to which the Patient or Asset is actually saved.
attributes.agent: The sentient being who rescues the Patient or Asset from the Harmful_situation.
attributes.patient: The living being who is rescued by the Agent.
attributes.instrument: The tool with which the Agent saves the Patient or Asset.
attributes.circumstances: The setting in which the rescuing act takes place.
attributes.manner: The way in which the Agent rescues the Patient or Asset.
attributes.time: The time at which the Agent rescues the Patient or Asset.
attributes.harmful_situation: An event that occurs which could result in injury or harm to the Patient or Asset.
attributes.asset: The entity that is judged to be valueable which might be lost or damaged by the Harmful_situation.
attributes.purpose: The purpose for which the Agent rescues the Patient or Asset.
attributes.place: The location at which the Agent rescues the Patient or Asset.
attributes.explanation: A state of affairs that the Agent is responding to in performing the action.

Judgment_communication(Event).description: A Communicator communicates a judgment of an Evaluee to an Addressee.  The judgment may be positive (e.g. praise) or negative (e.g. criticize), and this is indicated by the semantic types Positive and Negative attached to the lexical units.  This frame does not contain words where Evaluee and the Addressee are necessarily the same .

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.time: The point in time at which the Communicator berates or compliments the Addressee.
attributes.place: The location where the Communicator admonishes the Addressee.
attributes.result: This FE identifies the Result of an event.
attributes.frequency: This FE describes the frequency with which the specified communication occurs
attributes.extent_of_acclaim: The Extent_of_acclaim provides a description of the number or whereabouts of the Communicator.
attributes.topic: The Topic is the subject on which the Addressee is being judged.
attributes.manner: The Manner is the way in which the judgment is communicated.
attributes.means: The Means is the method employed to communicate the judgment.
attributes.reason: The Reason is why the Communicator forms the type of judgment they form.
attributes.role: The laudable or reprimandable status held by the Addressee.
attributes.depictive: The Depictive describes the state of the Communicator or Addressee.
attributes.medium: The Medium identifies the physical or abstract entity in which the judgment is conveyed.
attributes.evaluee: A judgment is made about the Evaluee  With verbs this FE is typically expressed as Object:
attributes.expressor: An action or entity under the control of the Communicator that expresses the criticism or praise directed towards the Addressee.
attributes.addressee: The Addressee is jduged by the Communicator and receives the message of approval or disapproval.
attributes.communicator: The Communicator communicates a judgment to the Addressee.
attributes.grounds: The Grounds describes the basis for the judgment.
attributes.degree: The Degree is the severity of the judgment.
attributes.internal_cause: The emotional or physical state of the Communicator that leads to their communication of a judgment.

Change_tool(Event).description: An Agent changes Tools, from the Old_tool to a New_tool.  The Tools may include vehicles, services providers, or more proto-typical implements.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.new_tool: The tool that the Agent ends up using.
attributes.purpose: The aim of the Agent when they carry out the change.
attributes.place: This FE identifies the place where the Agent makes a change.
attributes.agent: The individual that changes their situation.
attributes.iterations: The number of times that the action goes from start to finish.
attributes.old_tool: The tool that the Agent had been using.
attributes.means: The action of the Agent which brings about a change.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the time when the Agent acts intentionally.
attributes.tools: The entities controlled by an Agent to achieve some Purpose.
attributes.manner: Any description of the Agent's change which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of an Agent that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).

Hold(Event).description: The words in this frame describe the manipulation of an Entity by an Agent.  Generally, this implies that the Entity is not deeply or permanently physically affected, nor is it overall moved from one place to another.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.place: The location where the Manipulator manipulates the Victim.
attributes.agent: The Agent manipulates an object. Agent typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  Agent is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs:
attributes.means: An act of the Manipulator that enables them to alter the action of the Victim.
attributes.result: This FE identifies the Result of manipulation.
attributes.time: The time when the manipulation occurs.
attributes.locus: The Agent's manipulation of an Entity may be further specified as being localized to some part of the Entity, a Locus.  The Locus is usually expressed as a PP Complement.
attributes.explanation: A state of affairs leading to the manipulation.
attributes.duration: This FE identifies the Duration of the manipulation.
attributes.bodypart_of_agent: The part of the Agent's body being used to manipulate the Entity may also be expressed. While the default is for an Agent to use his/her hands, other body parts may be specified. This frame element usually occurs as a PP-complement.
attributes.entity: The Entity being manipulated often occurs as the direct object of verbs:
attributes.depictive: This FE identifies a depictive phrase describing the Agent or Bodypart_of_agent that holds throughout the action.
attributes.purpose: A state-of-affairs that the Manipulator is hoping to bring about by manipulating the Victim.
attributes.instrument: An entity that the Manipulator uses to get the Victim to perform the Resulting_action.
attributes.particular_iteration: Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.
attributes.manner: Any description of the event which is not covered by more specific FEs, including metaphorical force (hard, softly), secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). It may also indicate salient characteristics of a Manipulator that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
attributes.resulting_action: What the Manipulator intends to make the Victim do and the Victim actually does.
attributes.manipulator: The person who gets the Victim to act against their interest.
attributes.goods: The FE goods is anything (including labor, time, or legal rights) that can be taken away.
attributes.victim: The person who the Manipulator gets to do something they would not have done had no pressure or deception been applied.
attributes.degree: This FE identifies the Degree to which an event occurs.

Being_in_operation(Event).description: A Device or machine is in (or out of) service. Note that being broken or functional is a separate issue from being turned on or off. This latter notion is what the present frame is concerned with.  The Time when and the Place where the Device is in use may be specified, as may be the Purpose a backgrounded human User had in turning the Device on or off.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.place: The Place in which the Device is or is not operating.
attributes.device: The Device or machine that is in or out of operation.
attributes.time: The Time when a Device is in or out of operation.
attributes.duration: Duration denotes the length of time from the beginning of a continuous situation (the one denoted by the target) to its end.
attributes.degree: The extent to which the Artifact exceeds or falls short of the minimum requirements for being operational.
attributes.object: The entity with an understood purpose.

Recording(Event).description: An Agent sets down in permanent form information about the occurrence of a Phenomenon. Alternatively, the Agent records that an Entity had a particular Value for one of its Attributes.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.time: This FE identifies the Time when the Agent creates the record of the Phenomenon.
attributes.period_of_iterations: This FE denotes a duration in which the recording event occurred iteratively.
attributes.means: This FE identifes the action whereby the Agent creates a record of the Phenomenon.
attributes.duration: Duration denotes the length of time from the beginning of a continuous situation (the one denoted by the target) to its end. In many cases, the continuous situation is a dynamic action which is ongoing, while in others it is simply an undifferentiated state.
attributes.entity: An Entity for which the Agent records the Value of an Attribute.
attributes.value: The Value of the Entity that is recorded for the specified Attribute.
attributes.instrument: The Agent uses an Instrument in order to create a record of the Phenomenon or to measure an Entity's Value for a specified Attribute.
attributes.phenomenon: The Phenomenon is the entity or situation in the world of which a Agent becomes aware.
attributes.purpose: The goal that the Agent has in mind in creating a record of the Phenomenon.
attributes.degree: The extent to which the Phenomenon has been documented.
attributes.agent: The Agent is the sentient entity that creates a permanent record of the Phenomenon.
attributes.medium: Medium is the physical entity in which the Agent creates a record of their impression of the Phenomenon.
attributes.language: The symbolic system used by the Agent.
attributes.frequency: The amount of times the Agent records something per unit of time.
attributes.manner: Any description of the event which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). It may also indicate salient characteristics of an Agent  that also affect the action (deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
attributes.place: The location where the Agent sets down the facts.
attributes.attribute: That feature of the Entity which is under discussion.

Carry_goods(Event).description: A Distributor sells, lends, or otherwise distributes a class of Goods. In the prototypical case, the Distributor is a retailer who generally keeps some type of Goods on site for the purpose of selling it to a buyer. Extensions include lending Goods (e.g., libraries, movie rental outlets), organization-internal distribution (as in a hospital), or other non-commercial distribution centers. The Goods are constrained to be a type of item (e.g., canned goods, antique dressers) rather than a particular or unique item (e.g., Smith's last self-portrait, that guitar I saw here last week). Note that a Distributor may carry some particular goods, but may not have it on hand at that exact moment.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.distributor: The Distributor maintains a store of Goods for the purpose of selling or otherwise distributing them.
attributes.place: The Place indicates where the carrying of Goods occurs.
attributes.duration: This FE indicates the length of time that the Distributor carries the Goods.
attributes.goods: The Goods are kept on hand and distributed by the Distributor.
attributes.time: The Time when the Distributor carries the Goods.
attributes.frequency: This frame element is defined as the number of times an event occurs per some unit of time. A Frequency expression answers the question how often.
attributes.manner: Any description of the storing of goods which is not covered by more specific FEs, including general descriptions comparing events (the same way) and salient characteristics of a Distributor that also affect the action (deliberately, carefully).

Cost(Event).description: A Payer gives up (or potentially gives up) the use of an Asset (generally money) in order to achieve an Intended_event.  This event is often more specifically described as gaining possession of some Goods or receiving a Service.  In the majority of cases, the Payer is described generically (INI), and the situation depicted answers the question of how much of an Asset would have to be given up to receive the Goods or bring about the Intended_event.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.intended_event: The event that the Payer brings about by deploying the Asset.
attributes.payer: The person whose Asset is given up in order to achieve an Intended_event.  This FE is often expressed as INI.
attributes.degree: This FE identifies the Degree to which Goods are cheap or expensive.
attributes.asset: The price of or payment made for the Goods.
attributes.goods: The FE Goods is the item(s) whose price is being assessed.  Goods is usually an External Argument:
attributes.origin: The place where a transaction would take place, generally where Goods and services are created or sold.
attributes.time: The time when a transaction takes place.
attributes.rate: The amount of an Asset relative to some measure of the Goods

Departing(Event).description: After a visit is complete, the Agent departs the Source, normally bound for their normal haunts.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.speed: This frame element labels words or phrases that describe how quickly the Theme is moving. He quickly exited the crowded terminal.
attributes.means: The action of the Theme which results in its departure. He retreated from his opponent by taking a quick leap backwards.
attributes.time: The Time at which the departure takes place.We left in the morning.
attributes.purpose: This FE identifies the Purpose for which the Theme departs from the Source.
attributes.agent: This is the individual which moves under their own power.
attributes.source: All the verbs in this frame express some change of location, away from one place and to another. Any constituent that expresses the initial position of the Theme, before the change of location, is tagged with Source. Often the Source is understood from context. The woman left. DNI The woman left the house.We departed from New York on Friday.
attributes.distance: The distance that the Theme has traveled. He withdrew a little from her.
attributes.mode_of_transportation: The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Theme is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Theme. Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium.
attributes.place: The Place is the location in which the departing takes place.
attributes.manner: Any expression which describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion expresses the frame element Manner. Descriptions of steadiness, grace, and many other things count as Manner expressions, though Speed and Means should be tagged using the more specific FE labels. The messenger left the room clumsily.
attributes.goal: This FE labels any expression which tells where the Theme ends up, or would end up, as a result of departing from the Source. Our visitors left for Los Angeles.
attributes.path: Any description of the trajectory of the departure which is neither a Source nor a Goal expresses the frame element Path.  In this frame, Path expressions almost always have a sense meaning 'via'.
attributes.self_mover: This is the entity which moves under its own power.
attributes.depictive: Depictive identifies a phrase which describes the Theme at the time of departing.
attributes.cotheme: The Cotheme is the second moving object, expressed as a prepositional phrase generally headed by 'with' or 'along with'.
attributes.containing_event: This FE denotes an event that occurs or state of affairs that holds at a time that includes the time during which the event or state of affairs reported by the target occurs and of which it is taken to be a part.
attributes.new_situation: An unexpected event that affects some agent (usually the Self_mover), which is enabled by, and occurs after, the departing.
attributes.vehicle: The Vehicle is the means of conveyance that the Traveller disembarks from.
attributes.explanation: The Explanation is the motivation or explanation for why the Theme departs.
attributes.path_shape: The configuration formed by the entire Path of the Self_mover, taken simultaneously.
attributes.duration_of_final_state: The length of time that the Theme stays away from the Source location.
attributes.re-encoding: This FE presents the current frame as an integral part of a larger conceptualization expressed by another frame.
attributes.intended_goal: Any expression which tells where the Self_mover intends to end up as a result of the motion.
attributes.coordinated_event: The label Coordinated_event is to be used for phrases denoting an event (it does not allow states) that the departing is rhythmically aligned with. (This would then further require that the departing be iterated.)  The Coordinated_event is conceived of as independent: it would occur regardless of the event expressed by the target, which is not even an incidental or optional sub-part of the Coordinated_event.
attributes.frequency: The Frequency is the rate at which each Theme departs.
attributes.reciprocation: An event paired with the motion, which explains why the motion is expected. In particular, Reciprocation is used to indicate an action that is being rewarded or punished by the motion, and/or is paired with the motion as the other side of an agreement.
attributes.direction: The direction in which the Self_mover goes.
attributes.circumstances: Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
attributes.result: The state of the Self_mover at the end of the event.
attributes.traveller: The Traveller is the entity which disembarks from the Vehicle.
attributes.host: The Host allows the Visitor to use his/her resources, and to remain temporarily at the Host_location.
attributes.host_location: The Visitor departs from the Host_location, a location strongly associated with the Host.
attributes.visitor: The Visitor departs from the location of the Host.
attributes.journey: The Journey is the trip or expedition on which the Theme embarks. Mr. Burns departed on a hunting expedition.
attributes.event_description: This FE describes of the state of affairs denoted by the Departing event as role fillers in other frames; the state of affairs reported Departing event is understood to play a role in the state of affairs of the modifier.
attributes.theme: This is the object which moves. It may be an entity which moves under its own power, but it need not be. The officer left the house.
attributes.iterations: The frame element Iterations is used for expressions that indicate the number of times an event or state (of the kind denoted by the target in its clause) has taken place or held.

GiveUp(Event).description: An Agent leaves behind a Theme effectively rendering it no longer within their control or of the normal security as one's property.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.agent: The Agent is the person who acts to leave behind the Theme.
attributes.explanation: Explanation denotes a proposition from which the act of abandonment logically follows.
attributes.duration: For what expanse of time the Agent has given up the Theme.
attributes.event_description: A description of the event as a whole.
attributes.degree: The extent to which the Agent leaves the Theme behind.
attributes.manner: The style in which the Agent gives up the Theme.
attributes.theme: The Theme is the entity that is relinguished to no one from the Agent's possession.
attributes.time: When the Agent gives up the Theme.
attributes.place: The location where the Agent gives up the Theme.
attributes.purpose: The purpose for which the Agent abandons the Theme.
attributes.means: An action performed by the Agent that accomplishes the action indicated by the target.
attributes.depictive: The FE Depictive describes the Agent during the abandoning event.

Change_of_leadership(Event).description: This frame concerns the appointment of a New_leader or removal from office of an Old_leader.  The Selector brings about the change in leadership, for example, by electing or overthrowing a leader. Some words in the frame describe the successful removal from office of a leader (e.g. depose, oust), others simply the attempt (e.g. uprising, rebellion).

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
attributes.circumstances: This frame element describes the situation that brought about the change of leadership.
attributes.manner: This FE is used for the Manner of performing an action.
attributes.old_order: The FE Old_order identifies the political order that existed before the change of leadership occurs.
attributes.new_leader: With words denoting appointment to a position, the New_leader is typically the object of verbs.
attributes.selector: The Selector (most commonly a group of people) is responsible for a change in leadership.  Typically, it occurs as the External Argument of verbs.
attributes.body: A group of individuals who are elected or appointed to perform some function of governance.
attributes.depictive: Depictive indicates the state of one of the participants during the action.
attributes.function: The Function is the purpose the New_leader will fufill.
attributes.degree: This FE indicates the Degree to which an event occurs.
attributes.role: Frequently the Old_leader or New_leader is referred to only by his/her role. However, the Role can be expressed separately from the leader, usually as either a secondary predicate or in a PP Complement.
